title: Why Do $200,000,000 Games Keep Getting Canceled? | EA’s Black Panther Greenlight Failure

rawLines.text: [Music]
All right, Adam, we've saved 20 minutes
for you for our philosophy corner. Here
we go. Philosophy Corner. Okay, so the
topic here is around the problem with
AAA greenlights. So, there is an
excellent article by Owen Mahoney,
ex-president of Nexon called Sympathy
for the Devil, which he went through
basically the problem with green lights.
Also last week we discussed there was
the recent news that EA has canled and
shut down the studio working on Black
Panther. Jason Shrier came out
afterwards and came out and with
additional context some quotes here from
the article. The news came as a shock
specifically to the team. Black Panther
had recently passed what EA called a
development gate. The team had momentum.
The project was coalescing and the rumor
behind this was that EA executives were
frustrated that the game had not left
pre-production phase after nearly four
years in development. And for context
around this four years, this might be a
surprise for people coming from mobile.
It's not unheard of in AAA to have a
4-year pre-production cycle. Six to
eight-year productions are unfortunately
becoming more and more the norm for some
of these epic scale AAA openw world
games. We need to try to find a way to
to solve this. 6 to 8 year cycles lead
to a lot of bad things, but especially
when you've got a new studio, a new
engine working through COVID, you've got
a recipe for these kind of six to eight
year productions. So this blog post
specifically talks through the challenge
of making a decision at a green light
and Owen Mahoney as I said president of
Nexon from 2014 to 2024 CFO from 2010 to
2014 and then previously was corp dev at
EA. The challenge here of like a green
light meeting is sitting and putting
your head in the the executives's mind
here. Do you trust this plan right this
plan as presented? Do you believe this
game will be fun? Will it sell? Will it
cost as much as they're saying it will
cost? Or how many delays do you bake
into your mind that this thing will
actually cost? Really? Do you plus the
plan, the team? And unfortunately, can
you even say no? And I think this is
where we get into a lot of the some cost
fallacy, but there is a lot more
pressure to stay with the default path
of saying yes than there is to say no
and to cancel. There's tremendous amount
of talent risk. There's cost risk. But
sunk cost fallacy is real. And of
course, what this translates to is most
of these green lights end up never being
a full no unless there's a smoking gun.
It ends up being more like yes, but with
caveats or yes with additional concerns.
So digging into things like is this
actually fun, right? The team is
presenting the world, the art being
pretty, bugs are getting squashed,
momentum is good, but unfortunately most
of these green lights don't focus on
whether it's actually working, if the
game is actually fun, if the game will
actually sell. It typically focuses a
lot more on production momentum than it
does on commercial viability. Typically
research backs up some of these
decisions. So they're bringing in
saying, "Hey, we got great fun scores.
Players are loving it." But the reality
is I think much of this research,
especially presented by the game teams,
can be bent, can be adjusted, can have
the finger on the scale. Additionally,
sort of plans are then built. You know,
maybe it's not fun now. Maybe the
executives don't have full trust yet,
but hey, trust us, it will be in x
amount of months and then eventually the
big decision around a delay can happen.
And this goes into the article around
like do you kill the game? Do you force
the date or do you delay? And of course,
if you delay, then you're killing
credibility with your board. So
answering all of this in a 90-minute
meeting is just not realistic. The big
flaws with this is that most executives
assume linear progression of games. When
games are jungles, even in production,
there's always going to be es and flows
in conviction and momentum. Big
decisions are happening in these
meetings with actually pretty limited
information. You know, no one in these
meetings ever says that there's not
enough information. Teams put together
decks and decks and decks, tons of
spreadsheets of checklists, but
ultimately most of these green lights
turned into a dog and pony show. This
then starts to emphasize more around the
schedule than around fun and commercial
viability. And this is especially true
because burn rates are intense in AAA
reaching 30, 40, 100 million yearly burn
rates. So the problem then becomes these
green lights frontload the wrong risks.
Dex becomes more important than
software. A good sounding strategy
becomes better than execution. Having
amazing pretty artwork becomes more
important than real fun. Having those
pretty pictures for your decks,
tutorials become more important than
deep systems to make sure execs have fun
in the 15 minutes that they actually
play in these green lights. And USPS is
more important than the game to get your
marketing team on your side in these
meetings. So this all points towards
like clear underlying issues that like
the process in which we build out these
green lights. The way that we kind of
coales this decision puts a lot of
emphasis on the wrong things as well. He
points at things like tools development
process and our overfocus on graphics as
our selling point makes this problem
worse and
worse. So my take on the article is that
I think this is absolutely a discussion
that we need to be having. That's why
I'd like to bring it up here and I'd
like to have even more discussion after
this podcast. What I'm missing from the
article is actually a discussion on real
solutions since I think in general,
yeah, 90minute meetings with 30 plus
executive stakeholders are just never
going to be the forum where decisions
are really made. Like these will always
be dog and pony shows because
unfortunately there's too high of a
stakes. There's too many stakeholders in
the room. The reality is that there's
just going to have to be more sort of
closed-door meetings afterwards where
the teams objectively evaluate the
momentum. And that's why like most of
the stuff will end up being more dog and
pony shows as long as everybody's
careers and stakes rely on it. It's
really hard for any game team to present
an objective truth about their own game.
And as games become more complex, it's
no longer just about the box and about
USPS for executives to have conviction
in these investments, it takes a lot
more granular checklists and breakouts
of objective experts bubbling up a
clearer look at the overall game health.
Like especially as we're talking about
not just box premium products, we're
also talking about live services. It's
not just like, hey, the USPS look good.
It's the fun, it's the retention, it's
everything else. So on top of this,
research and forecasts are flawed.
Research can be bent. Forecasts can be
goal seeking rather than bottoms up
reality. Making P&L's typically a pretty
useless exercise. So what's better is
having a conversation mapping execution
against key assumptions in those
forecast, key assumptions in that
research to make sure that we're always
saying like, hey, we said this game
relies on XYZ to exceed. Do we believe
we can get there? and constantly having
a very objective analysis of that to
drive the decision here. That's not
simple, but that has to come top down
mandate. That that's the way that you
make decisions. And in general, you have
to embrace the fact that game companies
are terrible at killing games in
general. Like I did I literally did a
GDC talk about this I think 10 years
ago. Even though I talked about killing
games, like Wuga was [ __ ] at it to be
completely clear. Like we talked about,
oh my god, we kill games all the time.
It's like no, we were pretty [ __ ] at
killing games. We're even talking about
Supercell. Like Supercell, hey, we kill
games all the time. Super, you're also
[ __ ] at it. I'm sorry. AAA devs never
can make a decision quickly. So, this is
the really hard part. It's like, how do
you break people out of their human
nature, saying, "Yes, but please fix
some things is easy versus fighting
against some cost fallacy, objectively
looking at the evaluation, and
understanding when you're really off
track." That's a really difficult
problem. What I really appreciate about
the blog post was that him just calling
this out for everything that we all feel
every time we go into one of these
meetings, no matter what side of the
table you're on. If you're on the game
side, you're like, "Uh, it's a dog and
pony show. I just have to figure out how
to tell them what they want so they
greenlight me." And if you're on the
executive side, you're like, "I know
they're bullshitting me and they just
want a green light and what I'm really
looking at might not actually be true."
And so I think there is a lot of human
nature of how do you actually have a
real conversation about the real state
of the game. And one of the things that
you pulled out that I thought was really
interesting and I wanted to talk about
was research and how difficult research
can be and how much of a crutch it can
be either way depending on how objective
your research team is. In some cases,
your research team goes native and then
they just support the game team and
other times they're too harsh. And other
times it is garbage in, garbage out.
Adam, and you and I were talking about
this before the podcast is you can get
false positives or false negatives if
the assets you're putting into research
don't do a good job of reflecting what
the product is. Because players and
consumers can never ever tell you what
they want. they can only react to the
stimulus that you're showing them. And
if your stimulus sucks and you're doing
a bad job, then you're going to not get
great data coming out at that. And I
would say even to that point, like the
executive team can never be worried
about that, right? Like I have never met
an executive that's going to go like,
"Oh, that research, what was the exact
asset that you tested with? Is that an
unbiased?" Like nobody's going that deep
into the research, right? Because they
don't have time. It's a 90-minute
meeting. The bedrock of our decision is
like, hey, this number is green, right?
Yep. But the reality is that that number
was created in an biased way. Then it
becomes, how are we really making good
decisions at this point? Yeah. Every
research deck, you know, I either read
or work on has 50 pages. And you're
right. So, it's like all of these
different insights. I mean, the time and
energy I put into creating the assets. I
was on a project last year where I spent
so much time going into and creating
what is the paragraph that we show
people first. How do we talk about the
USPS and different features? How do we
talk about what we want to understand?
And then what is like a visual asset
that we're creating that showcases the
gameplay when the game team only has
like gray box stuff to show. What do I
make up and put in there? How do I tell
the story? What's the voice over? like
those assets are crucial and then how do
I make sure the game team isn't like
gonna [ __ ] all over the assets that we
know we jointly created together so that
they then [ __ ] on the results and say oh
well that's not actually true about the
game and so to me one of the places I
think we should all put more attention
and focus on is in that early stage play
testing consumer research so I wanted to
ask you actually you know a lot of what
we you know we talk about mobile all the
time should AAA Hey, start taking
learnings from, this is going to sound
crazy, from hyper casual studios who
prototype things more quickly, who get
to things more quickly just in terms of
like finding the fun and the play
without worrying about, you know, the
beautiful crazy graphics and the
beautiful art in a sense. Do we care as
much about that in finding the fun? I
know it's not a perfect one for one and
you're not going to like take a shitty
hyper casual game and be like this is
the next W which are four with a tech
demo that's the most beautiful thing
you've ever seen but are there
learnings? Am I crazy? The only point I
was going to make is that these
decisions get so complicated because
they're mired in a bunch of other
decisions that have been made whether
you know Laura Mielli is on the hot seat
right now because she got the Star Wars
licenses, she got these Marvel licenses
and they have to make use of them,
right? So there are financial
considerations about how much money they
spent for these licenses and and what
their contract is required to, right?
With the Star Wars license, for
instance, they never hit the milestones
that they were required to. So they
canceled projects and whatever else. So,
this is actually Laura is like really in
in a tough spot here because any she was
in charge of those two licenses as far
as I'm concerned. Yeah, the cancellation
fee is like tens of millions of do. I
mean, I'm guessing. I actually don't
know, but I would imagine and they have
to have a certain amount of projects in
development or whatever. So, they still
have these these things going, right?
They evidently still have Iron Man and
maybe one other Marvel game, but they
definitely have another Star Wars game.
So, those are part of the considerations
that have nothing to do with the actual
assets and the and the development
process or whatever. The other thing
that like a little bit of context for
this is that EA has been trying to build
an action game since the 2000s, dude. I
think since the '9s, right? They've been
trying to be competitive. They had
Action Girl for a while. I think in
Montreal they built that Superman game
in Tibbron that was [ __ ] terrible,
right? Like they made those Lord of the
Rings movie games. Remember those? Those
were good. Those were good. I thought
those were good. But they really wanted
like a single character action game and
they finally made one with the Star Wars
game, right? The Star Wars game was like
kind of their first success in that
genre material success. So they've been
trying to build this stuff for a long
time. So there's that as well that
they're like trying to be competitive in
that space and they're using these
licenses to do so. So there's political
pressure there. So what I'm trying to
say is that these green light processes
are far more complex because there are
other business considerations that are
not part of what the game is. there's
other things that are going on that
needs to be, you know, Laura needs to
prove that these licenses were worth
getting, right? And so, like, you can't
cancel a project like that, you know,
after signing these big licenses. You
know what I'm saying? So, like there's
political pressure there, you know, like
I don't know, there's all kinds of
considerations. I'm not close to this
one at all, so I don't really know
exactly what's going on, but it's just
something to keep in mind. I'm sure that
like slowed down any decision-m process,
right? Like the weight of you signed up
for this license, you're telling me 4
years after pre-production that we're
now going to cancel it. Yeah. Yeah.
Yeah. Like that. Yeah. But I guess to
your point on like hyper casual, that is
insanely tough. Let's think of this as
like AAA single player action adventure
games, I don't think there's a lot of
learnings you can apply from hyper
casual given like how much time it would
take to get to a testable state for
these games that would apply in any sort
of hyper casual style test. the way that
they think about it, right? You've got
small teams prototyping different kinds
of play patterns rapidly getting to a
playable thing. It feels like, yeah, I
listen, I get it. Like, you know, can
you mock that up to be the next Jedi
Survivor or the next whatever? I get
that's tough. But are AAA teams so stuck
to the point of this article in the old
ways, in the old best practices that
people aren't taking a step back and
saying, "Hey, could we prototype
differently? Could we mock something up
in a different way?" I I guess that's
just my challenge. And maybe I I was in
going extreme and saying like hey the
voodoo method of prototyping 2,000
things like I'm just going to extreme
just to say that AAA is stuck in the
other extreme which nothing has changed
in the way that you make a AAA game in
20 years and I find that concerning.
Yep. Absolutely. So there is a part of
this around getting faster to a faster
to fun faster to a testable state better
benchmarks for really really early in
production so it can gives you the
signal but like the issue with hyper
casual is hyper casual lives or dies
based on CPI and D1 retention and they
actually don't care so much about D30.
They don't care so much about some of
those longerterm metrics. Yeah. So
that's why like even hyper casual
doesn't always apply directly to normal
mobile games, right? Like you still do
CPI tests, you still do as many of these
things, but because hyper casual could
frontload so much of their risk in terms
of those early signal metrics, that
meant that those iteration cycles could
be that fast, which is great for them.
for AAA. You're we're still talking
about like can we get 8 million, 10
million, 15 million people to pay 70
bucks, 80 bucks for this game? That is a
lot harder problem. Absolutely. No, I I
I hear you. I just in the world of
solutions, how do you teach, you know,
300 person AAA team how to get unstuck
from the ways that they've been doing
things? I think we need better objective
tools to break teams out of that earlier
in production. I just don't know what
those are yet.
All right. Well, well done. We're not
solving the world's problems here on
today's podcast. We are only surfacing
them. I like the fact that Owen Mahoney
after being CEO for a while and CFO of
Nexon's out there just
philosophizing, you know, like he's out
there writing LinkedIn article like
league article like just throwing
grenades like getting the discussion
going. I think that's good. I love it.
Yeah. All right, everyone. That wraps it
up for this week. We will see you next
week.
[Music]

cleanText:
[Music]

All right, Adam, we've saved 20 minutes for you for our philosophy corner. Here we go. Philosophy Corner. Okay, so the topic here is around the problem with AAA greenlights. So, there is an excellent article by Owen Mahoney, ex-president of Nexon, called "Sympathy for the Devil," which he went through basically the problem with green lights. Also, last week we discussed there was the recent news that EA has canceled and shut down the studio working on Black Panther. Jason Shrier came out afterwards and came out and with additional context, some quotes here from the article. The news came as a shock specifically to the team. Black Panther had recently passed what EA called a development gate. The team had momentum. The project was coalescing, and the rumor behind this was that EA executives were frustrated that the game had not left pre-production phase after nearly four years in development. And for context around this four years, this might be a surprise for people coming from mobile. It's not unheard of in AAA to have a 4-year pre-production cycle. Six to eight-year productions are unfortunately becoming more and more the norm for some of these epic scale AAA open-world games. We need to try to find a way to solve this. Six to eight-year cycles lead to a lot of bad things, but especially when you've got a new studio, a new engine working through COVID, you've got a recipe for these kind of six to eight-year productions. So this blog post specifically talks through the challenge of making a decision at a green light, and Owen Mahoney, as I said, president of Nexon from 2014 to 2024, CFO from 2010 to 2014, and then previously was corp dev at EA. The challenge here of like a green light meeting is sitting and putting your head in the executives' mind here. Do you trust this plan, right, this plan as presented? Do you believe this game will be fun? Will it sell? Will it cost as much as they're saying it will cost? Or how many delays do you bake into your mind that this thing will actually cost? Really? Do you plus the plan, the team? And unfortunately, can you even say no? And I think this is where we get into a lot of the sunk cost fallacy, but there is a lot more pressure to stay with the default path of saying yes than there is to say no and to cancel. There's a tremendous amount of talent risk. There's cost risk. But sunk cost fallacy is real. And of course, what this translates to is most of these green lights end up never being a full no unless there's a smoking gun. It ends up being more like yes, but with caveats or yes with additional concerns. So digging into things like is this actually fun, right? The team is presenting the world, the art being pretty, bugs are getting squashed, momentum is good, but unfortunately most of these green lights don't focus on whether it's actually working, if the game is actually fun, if the game will actually sell. It typically focuses a lot more on production momentum than it does on commercial viability. Typically research backs up some of these decisions. So they're bringing in saying, "Hey, we got great fun scores. Players are loving it." But the reality is I think much of this research, especially presented by the game teams, can be bent, can be adjusted, can have the finger on the scale. Additionally, sort of plans are then built. You know, maybe it's not fun now. Maybe the executives don't have full trust yet, but hey, trust us, it will be in x amount of months and then eventually the big decision around a delay can happen. And this goes into the article around like do you kill the game? Do you force the date or do you delay? And of course, if you delay, then you're killing credibility with your board. So answering all of this in a 90-minute meeting is just not realistic. The big flaws with this is that most executives assume linear progression of games. When games are jungles, even in production, there's always going to be ebbs and flows in conviction and momentum. Big decisions are happening in these meetings with actually pretty limited information. You know, no one in these meetings ever says that there's not enough information. Teams put together decks and decks and decks, tons of spreadsheets of checklists, but ultimately most of these green lights turned into a dog and pony show. This then starts to emphasize more around the schedule than around fun and commercial viability. And this is especially true because burn rates are intense in AAA, reaching 30, 40, 100 million yearly burn rates. So the problem then becomes these green lights frontload the wrong risks. Decks becomes more important than software. A good-sounding strategy becomes better than execution. Having amazing pretty artwork becomes more important than real fun. Having those pretty pictures for your decks, tutorials become more important than deep systems to make sure execs have fun in the 15 minutes that they actually play in these green lights. And USPs is more important than the game to get your marketing team on your side in these meetings. So this all points towards like clear underlying issues that like the process in which we build out these green lights. The way that we kind of coalesce this decision puts a lot of emphasis on the wrong things as well. He points at things like tools development process and our overfocus on graphics as our selling point makes this problem worse and worse. So my take on the article is that I think this is absolutely a discussion that we need to be having. That's why I'd like to bring it up here and I'd like to have even more discussion after this podcast. What I'm missing from the article is actually a discussion on real solutions since I think in general, yeah, 90-minute meetings with 30 plus executive stakeholders are just never going to be the forum where decisions are really made. Like these will always be dog and pony shows because unfortunately there's too high of a stakes. There's too many stakeholders in the room. The reality is that there's just going to have to be more sort of closed-door meetings afterwards where the teams objectively evaluate the momentum. And that's why like most of the stuff will end up being more dog and pony shows as long as everybody's careers and stakes rely on it. It's really hard for any game team to present an objective truth about their own game. And as games become more complex, it's no longer just about the box and about USPs for executives to have conviction in these investments, it takes a lot more granular checklists and breakouts of objective experts bubbling up a clearer look at the overall game health. Like especially as we're talking about not just box premium products, we're also talking about live services. It's not just like, hey, the USPS look good. It's the fun, it's the retention, it's everything else. So on top of this, research and forecasts are flawed. Research can be bent. Forecasts can be goal-seeking rather than bottoms-up reality. Making P&Ls typically a pretty useless exercise. So what's better is having a conversation mapping execution against key assumptions in those forecast, key assumptions in that research to make sure that we're always saying like, hey, we said this game relies on XYZ to exceed. Do we believe we can get there? And constantly having a very objective analysis of that to drive the decision here. That's not simple, but that has to come top-down mandate. That's the way that you make decisions. And in general, you have to embrace the fact that game companies are terrible at killing games in general. Like I did I literally did a GDC talk about this I think 10 years ago. Even though I talked about killing games, like Wuga was [ __ ] at it to be completely clear. Like we talked about, oh my god, we kill games all the time. It's like no, we were pretty [ __ ] at killing games. We're even talking about Supercell. Like Supercell, hey, we kill games all the time. Super, you're also [ __ ] at it. I'm sorry. AAA devs never can make a decision quickly. So, this is the really hard part. It's like, how do you break people out of their human nature, saying, "Yes, but please fix some things is easy versus fighting against sunk cost fallacy, objectively looking at the evaluation, and understanding when you're really off track." That's a really difficult problem. What I really appreciate about the blog post was that him just calling this out for everything that we all feel every time we go into one of these meetings, no matter what side of the table you're on. If you're on the game side, you're like, "Uh, it's a dog and pony show. I just have to figure out how to tell them what they want so they greenlight me." And if you're on the executive side, you're like, "I know they're bullshitting me and they just want a green light and what I'm really looking at might not actually be true." And so I think there is a lot of human nature of how do you actually have a real conversation about the real state of the game. And one of the things that you pulled out that I thought was really interesting and I wanted to talk about was research and how difficult research can be and how much of a crutch it can be either way depending on how objective your research team is. In some cases, your research team goes native and then they just support the game team and other times they're too harsh. And other times it is garbage in, garbage out. Adam, and you and I were talking about this before the podcast is you can get false positives or false negatives if the assets you're putting into research don't do a good job of reflecting what the product is. Because players and consumers can never ever tell you what they want. They can only react to the stimulus that you're showing them. And if your stimulus sucks and you're doing a bad job, then you're going to not get great data coming out at that. And I would say even to that point, like the executive team can never be worried about that, right? Like I have never met an executive that's going to go like, "Oh, that research, what was the exact asset that you tested with? Is that an unbiased?" Like nobody's going that deep into the research, right? Because they don't have time. It's a 90-minute meeting. The bedrock of our decision is like, hey, this number is green, right? Yep. But the reality is that that number was created in an biased way. Then it becomes, how are we really making good decisions at this point? Yeah. Every research deck, you know, I either read or work on has 50 pages. And you're right. So, it's like all of these different insights. I mean, the time and energy I put into creating the assets. I was on a project last year where I spent so much time going into and creating what is the paragraph that we show people first. How do we talk about the USPs and different features? How do we talk about what we want to understand? And then what is like a visual asset that we're creating that showcases the gameplay when the game team only has like gray box stuff to show. What do I make up and put in there? How do I tell the story? What's the voice over? Like those assets are crucial and then how do I make sure the game team isn't like gonna [ __ ] all over the assets that we know we jointly created together so that they then [ __ ] on the results and say oh well that's not actually true about the game and so to me one of the places I think we should all put more attention and focus on is in that early stage play testing consumer research so I wanted to ask you actually you know a lot of what we you know we talk about mobile all the time should AAA, hey, start taking learnings from, this is going to sound crazy, from hyper casual studios who prototype things more quickly, who get to things more quickly just in terms of like finding the fun and the play without worrying about, you know, the beautiful crazy graphics and the beautiful art in a sense. Do we care as much about that in finding the fun? I know it's not a perfect one for one and you're not going to like take a shitty hyper casual game and be like this is the next W which are four with a tech demo that's the most beautiful thing you've ever seen but are there learnings? Am I crazy? The only point I was going to make is that these decisions get so complicated because they're mired in a bunch of other decisions that have been made whether you know Laura Mielli is on the hot seat right now because she got the Star Wars licenses, she got these Marvel licenses and they have to make use of them, right? So there are financial considerations about how much money they spent for these licenses and and what their contract is required to, right? With the Star Wars license, for instance, they never hit the milestones that they were required to. So they canceled projects and whatever else. So, this is actually Laura is like really in in a tough spot here because any she was in charge of those two licenses as far as I'm concerned. Yeah, the cancellation fee is like tens of millions of do. I mean, I'm guessing. I actually don't know, but I would imagine and they have to have a certain amount of projects in development or whatever. So, they still have these these things going, right? They evidently still have Iron Man and maybe one other Marvel game, but they definitely have another Star Wars game.
